_prev_prog_3.Description: The prevention program was developed in accordance with Process Safety Management (PSM) standards and RMP regulations.  The prevention program contains all the necessary elements as described in the RMP and PSM standard.  The prevention program is applicable to all ammonia and sulfur dioxide covered processes at Franzia Tulare.

The prevention program contains all the necessary elements as described in the RMP and PSM standard.  The prevention program is applicable to all ammonia covered processes at Franzia Tulare.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The management of Franzia Winery Tulare is committed to maintaining a safe work environment.  A Safety and Environmental Manager has been assigned to ensure that safe practices are followed in the specification and operation of systems involving hazardous chemicals.  This site has developed and trained an Emergency Response Team to ensure rapid and appropriate response to ammonia emergencies.  The site has specific and written evacuation, reporting, and response procedures in place to protect Franzia Winery Tulare employees, the public, and the environment in the event of an ammonia release. 
Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

The Franzia Winery Tulare facility covered by this RMP is located at 1887 N. Mooney Blvd. in Tulare, California.  The facility produces grape juice which is fermented into wine.   The facility uses sulfur dioxide for bacterial control and anhydrous ammonia for refrigeration.

Three stationary anhydrous ammonia refrigeration systems are used for chilling wine.  System A has eight chillers, System B has two chillers and System C has one chiller.  The potential total anhydrous ammonia charge in System A is 30,000 pounds.  System B has a potential total anhydrous ammonia charge to the system of 6,000 pounds.  System C has a potential total anhydrous ammonia charge to the system of 2,600 pounds. 

The sulfur dioxide system is located on the east sided of the winery.  The sulfur dioxide in the 1-ton cylinder serves as a supply to fill smaller hand-held sulfur dioxide cylinders ranging from 6-pound to 100-pound cylinders.  The sulfur dioxide is injected from the smaller cylinders into the wine to control the bacteria.  This system includes one filling station contain 2,000 pounds of sulfur dioxide, with up to 6,000 pounds (three cylinders) in storage.  This area is considered a single process totaling 8,000 pounds.  
The site includes an office/lab building; a c

ocument to ensure adequate preparedness with rapid and appropriate response to ammonia and sulfur dioxide release emergencies as well as other site emergencies.  The plan is maintained at the site?s Plant Office.  The document describes outside agency notification procedures in the event of ammonia or sulfur dioxide release, provides detailed evacuation procedures, and includes response procedures for the mitigation of minor ammonia releases.  The Fire Department will be used to respond to any non-minor leaks or leaks that cannot be repaired.  We have trained "Emergency Coordinators? In the event of a non-minor leak; we will evacuate and take initial life safety precautions.  This is also described in detail in the planning document.
